16.
LITIGATION RULINGS


16.1.
All the litigations that may arise between the parties during the period of application of the present Agreement, in relation with its
Articles, and that have not been solved in a friendly manner, will be subjected to the rulings of their respective Chief Executives. In
case of persistent disagreement, the litigation will be subjected to the General Management of Group Villar Mir.


16.2.
However, if any of the parties no longer belongs to Group Villar Mir, any litigation that may not be solved in a friendly manner will be
settled in compliance with the laws of Spain.


16.3.
Any doubt that arises, in the frame of this Agreement, will be settled through arbitration in equity, in compliance with the Spanish Law
of Arbitration, Ley 60/2003, both parties agreeing to obey the decision. For the designation of the arbitrators and the management of
the arbitration, the following rules will apply:


16.3.1.
There will be three arbitrators, solicitors. Each party will designate one, and these two will designate a third one.


16.3.2.
The place of arbitration will be Madrid.


16.3.3.
It will be governed by the laws of Spain and the language of the process will be Spanish.


16.3.4.
The arbitrators will dictate the decision within three months of the notice of the parties’ acceptance.


16.4.
The parties, expressly waiving the Jurisdiction that may correspond to the same, submit themselves to the jurisdiction of the Courts
and Tribunals of Madrid for any matter derived from the present Agreement that cannot be subjected to arbitration.

perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a legal contradiction by creating an exception to the arbitration clause. While initially stating that disputes will be settled through arbitration in accordance with Spanish law, it adds a provision allowing both parties to mutually agree to settle disagreements under South African law instead. This contradicts the initial clause's strict arbitration requirement and introduces uncertainty about which jurisdiction's laws would apply in the event of a dispute, making the clause more ambiguous and difficult to enforce.

perturbation.changed_text:
11.2.2.
10.2.2. EIT guarantees the control of access (through an access code and password) to information pursuant to the access
rights defined by the Customer, unless EIT determines that overriding such access is in the best interest of maintaining system integrity.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction to the data security guarantee. While EIT initially guarantees control of access to information based on the Customer's defined access rights, the added clause allows EIT to override those access rights if it deems it necessary for system integrity. This creates a potential conflict of interest, as EIT could use this clause to access data without the Customer's consent, undermining the original guarantee of controlled access and potentially violating data privacy regulations.

perturbation.changed_text:
10.3.
The liability of EIT will be limited to a value equal to contractual value as per clause 7.1 and will not exceed this value, unless damages are a direct result of gross negligence on the part of EIT, in which case liability shall be determined by EIT’s internal review board.
perturbation.explanation: This edit introduces a contradiction in the liability clause. Originally, EIT's liability is capped at the contractual value. The modification introduces an exception for gross negligence, but then delegates the determination of liability in such cases to EIT's internal review board. This creates a conflict of interest and undermines the enforceability of the original liability cap, as EIT essentially gets to decide the extent of its own liability, making it difficult for the Customer to seek fair compensation in cases of gross negligence.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contractual liability under Spanish law.
